terms.definition: A linear-time string matching algorithm that computes a Z-array where each entry stores the length of the longest substring starting from that position that matches a prefix of the string.
A standardized score indicating how many standard deviations a data point is from the mean of its distribution. It allows comparison of values from different distributions on a common scale.
A hybrid model from Zyphra that interleaves Mamba blocks with a shared attention layer for efficient long-context language modeling at 7B parameter scale.
A logical reasoning benchmark testing language models on constraint satisfaction problems. Evaluates systematic logical deduction capabilities.
A series of fine-tuned open LLMs from Hugging Face optimized for helpful assistants. Demonstrates how smaller models with good alignment can outperform larger base models.
Memory optimization technique from Microsoft DeepSpeed that partitions optimizer states gradients and parameters across devices. Enables training much larger models without full model replication.
Zero Redundancy Optimizer, a distributed training technique that partitions optimizer states, gradients, and parameters across data-parallel processes to reduce memory redundancy.
A model that generates novel views of an object from a single image by fine-tuning a diffusion model with camera pose conditioning.
A signal feature that counts the number of times a signal crosses zero within a frame. Used in speech and audio analysis to distinguish between voiced and unvoiced speech segments.
Novel vulnerabilities or attack vectors discovered in AI systems before developers know about them. AI security research increasingly focuses on finding such vulnerabilities proactively.
Adding "Let's think step by step" to a prompt to trigger reasoning without providing examples. A simple but effective technique for improving accuracy on complex tasks.
When AI performs a task without examples in the prompt, relying entirely on pre-trained knowledge and instructions. Contrasts with few-shot where examples are provided.

The development of zero-shot learning from early attribute-based approaches to modern large language models that perform tasks without task-specific training examples. GPT-3 (2020) demonstrated remarkable zero-shot capabilities through large-scale pre-training.

Named entity recognition performed on entity types not seen during training, using natural language descriptions of entity categories to generalize to new entity types without additional labeled data.
The ability to detect and localize objects of novel categories without any training examples, using vision-language alignment to match text descriptions of new categories to visual regions.
A security framework that requires continuous verification of all users devices and AI components regardless of their position within or outside the network boundary. Adapted for AI system security.
A zero-shot benchmark for long text understanding covering summarization question answering and aggregation tasks over long documents.
Next computing milestone beyond exascale targeting one zettaFLOPS or a sextillion operations per second. Expected to enable AI models of unprecedented scale in the late 2020s or early 2030s.
Popular 8-bit microprocessor from 1976 used in many early personal computers and embedded systems. Compatible with Intel 8080 code but added significant enhancements.
A database of commercially available chemical compounds for virtual screening. Contains over 230 million compounds used for drug discovery and molecular generation research.
A monocular depth estimation model that combines relative and metric depth estimation using a two-stage training approach for accurate real-world depth.
Electromechanical computer built by Konrad Zuse in 1941 in Berlin. Considered the world first programmable fully automatic digital computer using floating-point binary arithmetic.
